author: Tony Judt
summary: “It is simply not possible to envision any conceivable modern, urban-based economy shorn of its subways, its tramways, its light rail and suburban networks, its rail connections, and its intercity links.”
title: Bring Back the Rails! [Part 2]

author: Deb Olin Unferth
summary: Memories of the expat revolutionary scene in 1980s Nicaragua. An excerpt from Revolution: The Year I Fell in Love and Went to Join the War.
title: Internacionalista

author: Peter Maass
summary: The story behind the fall of Saddam’s statue in Baghdad.
title: The Toppling

author: Robert Huber
summary: A reporter heads to Istanbul, where Iverson is playing minor league hoops in a 3,200-seat arena and hanging out at T.G.I. Friday’s.
title: Allen Iverson: Fallen Star

author: Hanna Rosin
summary: A profile of South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley.
title: Good Ol' Girl

author: Matthew Brzezinski
summary: Arnold Weiss escaped Germany as a kid in 1938, leaving his family behind. He returned seven years later, now a U.S. intelligence officer tasked with tracking down fugitive Nazis. The ultimate revenge story.
title: Giving Hitler Hell

author: Thomas Lake
summary: A 15-year-old dies shortly after collapsing from heatstroke during a high school football practice. Was it has coach’s fault? The state thought so, and put him on trial.
title: The Boy Who Died of Football

author: Justin Vogt
summary: A profile of Mitch Landrieu, the first white mayor of New Orleans in nearly 30 years–part of a larger post-Katrina trend in the city’s politics. “The elected leadership looks almost like a photo negative of the pre-Katrina government.”
title: A Time Against Race

author: Ron Rosenbaum
summary: From the 1940s through the early 70s, incoming freshman at Harvard, Yale, Vassar, Wellesley, and several other top schools were photographed nude in the name of science–bogus science, as it turned out. Most of the photos were destroyed, but not all.
title: The Great Ivy League Nude Posture Photo Scandal

author: William D. Cohan
summary: On the (disputed) origins of the Huffington Post.
title: Huffing and Puffing

author: Patton Oswalt
summary: On how 21st century culture shifts killed the nerd and what lies ahead.
title: Wake Up, Geek Culture, Time To Die

author: Rob Walker
summary: The new purgatory; what becomes of digital identities after death.
title: Cyberspace When You're Dead

author: Natasha Vargas-Cooper
summary: How Internet porn has altered the ways we think about, and engage in, sex.
title: Hard Core

author: Sarah Ellison
summary: The backstory on Julian Assange’s relationship with the Guardian and the New York Times.
title: The Man Who Spilled the Secrets

author: Andrew Wolfson
summary: A caller poses as a policeman and convinces McDonald’s managers to strip-search a female employee. It’s not the first time.
title: A Hoax Most Cruel

author: Ronen Bergman
summary: Last year, an Mossad hit squad traveled to Dubai to assassinate a Hamas leader. They completed their mission, but were later humiliated when a twenty-seven minute video of their movements was posted online. How their cover got blown.
title: The Dubai Job

author: Paul Ford
summary: But the web is not just some kind of magic all-absorbing meta-medium. It's its own thing. And like other media it has a question that it answers better than any other. That question is:Why wasn't I consulted?
title: The Web Is a Customer Service Medium

author: Susan Orlean
summary: From 1968-1973, the three teenage Wiggin sisters, guided by a domineering father, played their strange music at New Hampshire ballrooms and recorded a single album. The Philosophy of the World LP goes for over $500 today, but the intervening decades have not been kind to the Wiggins.
title: Meet the Shaggs

author: Porter Fox
summary: The writer and his girlfriend move to the Dominican Republic, joining the rapidly expanding community of expats who claim to have found paradise. They promptly get robbed at gunpoint. To cope, he investigates the country.
title: Las Terrenas

author: Melanie Thernstrom
summary: On the last day of their junior year at Harvard, one roommate kills the other, then hangs herself. The press descends. A year later, a reporter searches for the real story.
title: Diary of a Murder

author: Mac McClelland
summary: On the utter brutality of life in the tent cities, one year after the earthquake.
title: Welcome to Haiti's Reconstruction Hell

author: Eliot Weinberger
summary: On George W. Bush’s memoir, Decision Points.
title: "Damn Right," I Said

author: Ken Silverstein
summary: On the political climate in Arizona.
title: Tea Party in the Sonora

author: Ben Goldacre
summary: Mattathias Rath made a fortune selling cure-all vitamins in Europe before moving his business to South Africa, where he launched a massive campaign against retroviral AIDS medications and in favor of his own vitamin cocktails. When scientists, AIDS non-profits, and even Medecins San Frontieres objected, he sued.
title: The Doctor Will Sue You Know

author: Nadya Labi
summary: On gay life in Saudi Arabia.
title: The Kingdom in the Closet

author: Hampton Sides
summary: On the psychology of a rescue worker after years of responding to disaster.
title: The Man Who Saw Too Much

author: Ariston Anderson, Francis Ford Coppola
summary: “As we enter into a new age, maybe art will be free. Maybe the students are right. They should be able to download music and movies. I’m going to be shot for saying this. But who said art has to cost money?”
title: Interview: Francis Ford Coppola

author: Michael Lewis
summary: Guz Dominguez says he was trying to help baseball players from Cuba; the U.S. government says he was smuggling athletes. The truth is more complicated.
title: Commie Ball: A Journey to the End of a Revolution

author: Joshua Davis
summary: A jogging buddy collapses during a marathon, his heart suddenly finished beating. The writer goes looking for answers.
title: Why My Friend Bill Died

author: Joshua Davis
summary: How to kick heroin in 24 hours.
title: Instant Detox

author: Lilia M. Schwarcz
summary: How the relationship between favela-based drug gangs and elite police units tasked with fighting them came to define Rio de Janeiro.
title: Rio’s New Reality Show

author: Paul Krugman
summary: How the dream of the Euro became a nightmare.
title: Can Europe Be Saved?

author: Seth Mnookin
summary: On the expanding community of American parents who believe, despite abundant evidence to the contrary, that there is a link between routine vaccinations and autism.
title: The Panic Virus

author: Hilton Als
summary: On Huck Finn, the book Nigger: The Strange Career of a Troublesome Word, and the evolution of language and race in America.
title: More Harm Than Good

author: Lynn Hirschberg
summary: A profile of the director, written from the set of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo.
title: David Fincher Gets the Girl

author: Caitlin Flanagan
summary: On a Duke student’s now infamous Powerpoint presentation of her sexual history; binge-drinking, post-feminism, and Mario Kart.
title: The Hazards of Duke

author: Ned Zeman
summary: The enigmatic life and death of Bruno Zehnder, who obsessively photographed penguins in the ice fields outside of a Russian base in Antarctica.
title: Death Among the Emperors

author: Andrew Corsello
summary: How a burst blood vessel transformed the mind of a deliberate, controlled chiropractor into that of an utterly unfiltered, massively prolific artist.
title: Metamorphosis

author: April Rabkin
summary: How the social networks that popped up in Facebook’s absence—the site is not available behind the Great Firewall—are changing Chinese culture.
title: The Facebooks of China

author: Jason Zengerle
summary: How a young state rep from Missouri, seemingly guaranteed political greatness, ended up behind bars.
title: The Idealist

author: Atul Gawande
summary: The decline of the American autopsy and what it says about modern medicine.
title: Final Cut

author: George Lois, Rocco Castoro
summary: George Lois never actually worked at Esquire, he simply designed the most iconic magazine covers of the 60s as a moonlighting gig while revolutionizing (and, generally pissing off) the advertising industry by day.
title: Interview: George Lois

author: Wright Thompson
summary: Searching for Jimmy Robinson, a boxer who fought Muhammad Ali in 1961, then disappeared.
title: Shadow Boxing

author: Dan Barry
summary: The transfiguration of Jared Loughner.
title: Looking Behind the Mug-Shot Grin of an Accused Killer

author: John Lahr
summary: On the late comedian Bill Hicks, just as a performance on Letterman is deemed unfit for network TV.
title: The Goat Boy Rises

author: Elizabeth Day
summary: A famed attorney begins a transformation away from being a man; and dies after a companion shoves her under an oncoming train.
title: The Extraordinary Life and Death of David Burgess

author: Jeffrey R. Young
summary: Fifteen years ago, Sherry Turkle developed a little crush on a robot named Cog. Since then, the MIT professor has been studying our ever-increasing emotional reliance on technology. She’s not optimistic about where we’re headed.
title: Programmed for Love

summary: A profile of the Time Man of the Year for 1963, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
title: America's Gandhi

author: Tom Junod
summary: A profile of Jobs. The themes: immortality, relinquishing control, and how being adopted affected his choices for Apple. The lede: “One day, Steve Jobs is going to die.”
title: Steve Jobs and the Portal to the Invisible

author: Joshua Davis
summary: A 134-pound magazine writer takes his chances at the U.S. Open sumo championships.
title: Supersize Me

author: Benjamin Schwarz
summary: On his 80th birthday; how Archie Leach, “the Bristol-born son of a part-Jewish suit presser,” became the greatest leading man of his generation.
title: Becoming Cary Grant

author: Todd S. Purdum
summary: A quasi-oral history of the party that was JFK’s 1961 inauguration.
title: From That Day Forth

author: Roberto Bolaño
summary: A 2000 speech on the impossibility of all forms of exile, particularly literary.
title: Literature and Exile

author: Tom Junod
summary: A profile of Roger Ailes, CEO of Fox News.
title: Why Does Roger Ailes Hate America?

author: John Mayer, Rob Tannenbaum
summary: Here’s what I really want to do at 32: fuck a girl and then, as she’s sleeping in bed, make breakfast for her. So she’s like, “What? You gave me five vaginal orgasms last night, and you’re making me a spinach omelet? You are the shit!” So she says, “I love this guy.” I say, “I love this girl loving me.” And then we have a problem.
title: Playboy Interview: John Mayer

author: Nate Berg
summary: When (temporary) cities swell; a short history of the Burning Man festival.
title: Burning Man and the Metropolis

author: Peter Baker
summary: Obama’s presidency may well be defined by whether or not he can curb unemployment. Step One: find a decent idea.
title: The White House Looks for Work

author: Gabriel Sherman
summary: A profile of A.J. Daulerio, editor of Deadspin and procurer of, among other things, cell phone pics of Brett Favre’s penis.
title: The Worldwide Leader in Dong Shots

author: Jonathan Cohn
summary: How health care reform could be repealed.
title: The Worst Case

author: John B. Judis
summary: “For the first time since the Civil War, the United States has a political party that is ideologically cohesive, disciplined, and determined to take power, even at the cost of disrupting the political system.”
title: Return of the Republicans

author: Evan Ratliff
summary: Most military experts agree that robots, not people, will inevitably do the fighting in ground wars. In Tennessee, a high-end gunsmith is already there. The story of Jerry Baber and his robot army.
title: Shoot!

author: Gay Talese
summary: After two years of filming Lawrence of Arabia, Peter O'Toole returns to his childhood home in Ireland.Plus: 50 years later, Gay Talese remembers the late Peter O'Toole.
title: Peter O'Toole on the Ould Sod

author: Jessica Lussenhop
summary: Forty years ago, a trio of student teachers created the most popular educational game of all-time.
title: Forging the Oregon Trail

author: Timothy Garton Ash
summary: On the illusion of the inevitable and the revolutions that ended the Eastern Bloc.

author: Lisa DePaulo
summary: The diary of a Scranton, PA National Guardsmen tasked with guarding the highest profile prisoner in U.S history: a surprisingly amiable Saddam Hussein.
title: Tuesdays with Saddam

author: Marjorie Williams
summary: A profile of then-First Lady Barbara Bush, published just before the 1992 presidential election. The lede: “Even Barbara Bush’s stepmother is afraid of her.”
title: Barbara's Backlash

author: John Gapper
summary: Searching for (and easily finding) Mark Augustus Landis, the man behind the “longest, strangest forgery spree the American art world has known.”
title: The Forger's Story

author: Rich Schapiro
summary: Nobody loved chimpanzees more than St. James Davis and his wife LaDonna; the couple spent more than 30 years—and gained a modicum of fame—raising one as their son. Then they almost died in a brutal chimp attack.
title: The Worst Story I Ever Heard

author: Geoffrey O'Brien
summary: On the young and ascendant Frank Sinatra, “who ruled crowds by seductive magnetism and surrounded himself with courtiers, but had once been an adolescent alone in his room listening to Bing Crosby on his Atwater-Kent.”
title: Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man

author: Dan P. Lee
summary: The life story of Travis the chimp and the family of tow truck operators who raised him like a human child before it all ended in tragedy.
title: Travis the Menace

author: Donald Katz
summary: A profile of the late Jack LaLanne, “the greatest gym teacher of all time,” who was as responsible as anyone for America’s fitness craze in the latter half of the 20th century.
title: Jack LaLanne Is Still an Animal

author: Kenneth Slawenski
summary: J.D. Salinger on the beaches on D-Day, marching through concentration camps, and in liberated Paris.
title: Holden Caulfield’s Goddam War

author: Atul Gawande
summary: Is long-term solitary confinement torture?
title: Hellhole

author: Claire Hoffman
summary: Bruce Wisan received one of the toughest assignments ever thrust upon an accountant; to take control of the assets (and by proxy, followers) of the polygamist Mormon breakaway sect, F.L.D.S., after their prophet, Warren Jeffs, went on the lam and their compound was raided.
title: Satan's Accountant

author: William D. Hartung
summary: Lockheed Martin is the largest government contractor in history. They train TSA workers and Guantanamo interrogators. Every American household pays them around $260 per year in taxes. The new military industrial complex is a single company.
title: How a Giant Weapons Maker Became the New Big Brother

author: Stephen Rodrick
summary: A primer on Peretz, longtime owner/editor of The New Republic, committed Zionist, and author of the line “Muslim life is cheap.”
title: Martin Peretz Is Not Sorry About Anything

author: Kevin Roose
summary: What has Ted Haggard, who left the New Life megachurch after admitting he purchased crystal meth and sexual favors from a male escort, been doing in the four years since? Selling insurance door to door and then… founding a new church and returning to the pulpit.
title: The Last Temptation of Ted

author: Josh Harkinson
summary: On the pair of entrepreneurs behind a Wal-Mart of weed in Oakland. The duo is talking IPO. “Everybody I was meeting was a little bit older, more a part of the hippie generation,” says one. “I was like, ‘I bet there’s so much room for innovation and new ideas.’”
title: Weedmart

author: Bill Keller
summary: On the cloak and dagger dealings between The New York Times and WikiLeaks. Adapted from Executive Editor Bill Keller’s forthcoming ebook, Open Secrets: WikiLeaks, War and American Diplomacy: Complete and Updated Coverage from The New York Times.
title: Dealing With Julian Assange and the Secrets He Spilled

author: Barry Siegel
summary: Paul Wayment made a profound mistake, left his 2-year-old son alone in his truck as he tracked deer in the wilderness. The boy was gone when he returned. The story of a collective struggle to find a just punishment.
title: A Father’s Pain, a Judge’s Duty, and a Justice Beyond Their Reach

author: William Langewiesche
summary: What happened when the founder of North Face and Esprit bought a chunk of Chile the size of a small state, intending to live with a select group inside it and turn it case study for ecological preservation. It turned out, however, that Chileans didn’t really like that idea.
title: Eden: A Gated Community

author: William Langewiesche
summary: In 1998, at age 45, Ken Bradshaw surfed the tallest wave in recorded history.
title: The Wave-Maker

author: Katie Baker
summary: A remembrance of relationships formed when the author, at 13 and using a false identity, frequented hockey chat rooms.
title: Confessions of a Former Adolescent Puck Tease

author: Tom Friend
summary: The story of Nate Fleming—walk-on point guard at Oklahoma State, fan favorite, golden child—and the 2001 plane crash that took his life.
title: Dear Nate

author: John Ptak
summary: On the language of hobos and the dictionaries it spawned.
title: Tramp-Speak of Antiquarian Road Warriors: ABC's of Tramps, Hobos and Vagabonds

author: Philip Weiss
summary: The Bohemian Grove is an exclusive, all-male club made up of Presidents, ambassadors, and other world leaders, with a 33 year waiting list for membership. Their booze-soaked annual retreat outside of San Francisco had never been infiltrated—until this story.
title: Masters of the Universe Go to Camp

author: Steven Hyden
summary: A year-by-year walk through of the decade that birthed a mainstream culture called ‘Alternative’ and the bands that were deified and destroyed by it.
title: Whatever Happened to Alternative Nation?

author: Daniel Zalewski
summary: A profile of director Guillermo del Toro.
title: Show the Monster

author: Adam Shatz
summary: A primer on Egypt’s political landscape.
title: Mubarak’s Last Breath

author: Kara Platoni
summary: Money from relatives abroad, the lifeline for many Afghani's, moves primarily through small hawala
title: The Afghan Connection

author: R. Kelly, Will Oldham
summary: On Sam Cooke, theme parties, and the importance of McDonald’s-related jingles when street performing.
title: Will Oldham Interviews R. Kelly

author: Danielle Sacks
summary: How YouTube went from ubiquitous to profitable; and where it goes next.
title: How YouTube's Global Platform Is Redefining the Entertainment Business

author: Brendan I. Koerner
summary: How a legally dubious FBI sting lured a pair of Russian hackers stateside.
title: From Russia With LØpht

author: A.C. Thompson, Lowell Bergman, Mosi Secret, Sandra Bartlett
summary: A year-long investigation of America’s coroners and medical examiners reveals a deeply flawed, deeply troubling system.
title: The Real CSI

author: Jonah Lehrer
summary: “I’m not the kind of guy who hears voices. But that night, as I passed the station, I heard a little voice coming from the back of my head…‘If you do it that way, if you use that algorithm, there will be a flaw. The game will be flawed. You will be able to crack the ticket. You will be able to plunder the lottery.’”
title: Cracking the Scratch Lottery Code

author: Yudhijit Bhattacharjee
summary: A trip to Râmnicu Vâlcea, a town of 120,000 where the primary (and lucrative) industry is Internet scams.
title: A Remote Town in Romania Becomes Cybercrime Central

author: Jack Nicholson, Louise Gannon
summary: Jack Nicholson interviewed at 73.
title: 'I used to feel irresistible to women. Not anymore': The melancholy confessions of Jack Nicholson

author: Michael Lewis
summary: How a nation went bankrupt. “Ireland’s regress is especially unsettling because of the questions it raises about Ireland’s former progress: even now no one is quite sure why the Irish suddenly did so well for themselves in the first place.”
title: When Irish Eyes Are Crying

author: Benjamin Wallace
summary: On the group of friends who came to rule the bizarre, decreasingly lucrative world of Internet porn.
title: The Geek-Kings of Smut

author: Becky Ferreira
summary: From the Greeks to George Lucas, 2,200 years of failure.
title: Humanity's Endless Quest to Invent a Death Ray: A History

author: Fred Vogelstein
summary: A requiem for the ‘content portal’ era.
title: How Yahoo Blew It

author: Michael Kelly
summary: Reporting from Kuwait on the week of its liberation, a brutal account of the atrocities committed during seven months of Iraqi occupation.
title: The Rape and Rescue of Kuwait City

author: David Grann
summary: Emmanuel “Toto” Constant, the founder of a barbaric Haitian paramilitary group, vanished from Port-au-Prince and resurfaced as a real estate agent in Queens.
title: Giving "The Devil" His Due

author: Rend Smith
summary: In the aftermath of a mysterious murder, exploring a part of the story that has received little attention: the young man who lost his life.
title: Something Happened at DC9. Who Did it Happen to?

author: John Ashbery, Kenneth Koch
summary: “What you say is very unclear, but I suppose you mean that since I find one of your remarks illogical and since I like your poems, that therefore I must like poems which are illogical. But I don’t find your poems either logical or illogical. If you want this interview to have the logic of a poem and not ordinary logic we will have to start over again.”
title: A Conversation between Kenneth Koch and John Ashbery

author: Bianca
summary: Supply and demand paid-sex economics, ‘hobbyist’ internet message boards, and the power of reviews.
title: Bianca, the Toronto Escort with a Day Job: Column #7

author: Yasmine El Rashidi
summary: February 1st, 2011. Tahrir Square, Cairo.
title: ‘Mubarak, Mubarak, What Have You Done?

author: Gay Talese, Katie Roiphe
summary: The original new journalist on his start at the Times, his daily writing routine, and why he’s always taken notes on shirt boards.
title: Gay Talese, The Art of Nonfiction No. 2

author: Geoffrey Gray
summary: The juvenile ward on Rikers Island is a world of constant violence fueled by gangs and, allegedly, encouraged and overseen by the guards.
title: The Lords of Rikers

author: S.L. Price
summary: The story of a small town just outside Pittsburgh that has suffered through a half-century of economic decline, racial tension, and endless crime. Despite that trajectory, or perhaps because of it, Aliquippa has also produced an astounding number of NFL players.
title: The Heart Of Football Beats In Aliquippa

author: Elizabeth Spiers
summary: Customer feedback on the New York City coke dealing industry.
title: The Perfect Dealer

author: Lawrence Wright
summary: During his 35 years as a member of the Church of Scientology, Oscar-winning writer and director Paul Haggis went “all the way to the top.” The story of why he left, and what happened once he did.
title: The Apostate

author: Dana Goodyear
summary: Reporting from inside the Church’s Celebrity Centre in Los Angeles.
title: Chateau Scientology

author: William Greider
summary: A newly minted, 34-year-old White House budget director gets a little too candid with a reporter profiling him during Ronald Reagan’s first year in office. Among Stockman’s many admissions: “None of us really understands what’s going on with all these numbers.”
title: The Education of David Stockman

author: Neal Stephenson
summary: What the twentieth century history of rocketry can tell us about innovation.
title: Space Stasis

author: C.J. Chivers
summary: How the Taliban reestablished itself as both a “quasi government” and a military force, and what that success means for the Pentagon’s plan to pass responsibility to Afghan forces by 2014.
title: Afghanistan's Hidden Taliban Government

author: Lauren Collins
summary: A profile of Arianna Huffington.
title: The Oracle

author: Marc Ambinder
summary: A look at what it takes to protect Mahmoud Ahmadinejad when he’s in New York City.
title: Inside the Secret Service

author: Chris Smith
summary: Cathie Black, former magazine executive, currently Bloomberg’s hand-picked Chancellor of New York City schools
title: "Just Smile"

author: Allison Hoffman
summary: A profile of Republican Eric Cantor: six-term congressman, new House majority leader, highest-ranking Jewish elected official in American history.
title: The Gentleman From Virginia

author: Tyler Cowen
summary: A primer on income inequality in America.
title: The Inequality That Matters

author: Andrew Delbanco
summary: On Mark Twain’s recently released memoir.
title: His Own Best Straight Best Man

author: Mary Anne Weaver
summary: On the Cairo knifing of 82-year-old Nobel Prize winner Naguib Mahfouz and its aftermath.
title: The Novelist and the Sheikh

author: Jason Fagone
summary: A profile of Vova Galchenko, teenage juggling virtuoso and early viral star.
title: As Seen on YouTube (and Pretty Much Only on YouTube)

author: John Jeremiah Sullivan
summary: A trip to Kingston, Jamaica to track down Bunny Wailer, a reggae legend now living “in his own private Zion.”
title: The Last Wailer

author: Lev Grossman
summary: Ray Kurzweil and the Singularity; when will our minds meld with the machine?
title: 2045: The Year Man Becomes Immortal

author: Steve Bogira
summary: On the enduring racial segregation in Chicago and why it’s an issue no mayoral candidate is willing to touch.
title: Separate, Unequal, and Ignored

author: Paul Amar
summary: An opinion piece on the structural causes of unrest in Egypt; the business fraternity, globalization, and the fate of Egyptian women.
title: Why Egypt's Progressives Win

author: Douglas Alden Warshaw
summary: When Conan O’Brien left NBC, he agreed to stay off TV for months and stay quiet about the network and its executives. The agreement contained no mention of social media, however. On the origins of a digital renaissance.
title: Conan 2.0

author: Scott Eden
summary: Brooklyn, Illinois has one of the most dense clusters of strip clubs and rubdown parlors in the entire country, drawing patrons from nearby St. Louis and its suburbs. Inside the clubs with the dancers, a strip club scholar, the mayor, and the regulars whose dollars keep the depressed local economy afloat.
title: Fantasies Made Fresh

author: Lawrence Wright
summary: The story of three months spent training reporters in Saudi Arabia, where the press is far from free. “I suspected that behind the closed gates of Saudi society there was a social revolution in the making. With some guidance, I thought, these journalists could help inspire change.”
title: The Kingdom of Silence

author: Luke O'Brien
summary: How a Nigerian-American conned upwards of $40 million from banks during the housing boom using publicly available information from the internet, persuasive storytelling, and prepaid cellphones, and then ditched his FBI tail in a casino.
title: The King of Home Equity Fraud

author: Aram Roston
summary: A look at the legislative lobbying efforts of Michael Bloomberg’s $7 billion-per-year company. While the mayor has no specific day-to-day role at Bloomberg LP, he maintains “the type of involvement that he believes is consistent with his being the majority shareholder.”
title: How Bloomberg Does Business

author: Steven Hyden
summary: “You’re either with Korn and Limp Bizkit, or you’re against them.” The birth of nu-metal.
title: Whatever Happened to Alternative Nation? — Part 9: 1998

author: James Verini
summary: The father: an Oscar-winning songwriter. The son, a college dropout and partier around downtown New York. Their alleged crimes; serial casting-couch rape (the senior) and a drowning murder in a Soho House bathtub (the junior).
title: The Curious Case of Joseph and Nicholas Brooks

author: David Segal
summary: How J.C. Penney gamed Google and became the top result for searches on everything from “area rugs” to “skinny jeans.”
title: The Dirty Little Secrets of Search

author: Tina Fey
summary: On the dilemmas facing a (very famous) working mother in New York City. “It is less dangerous to draw a cartoon of Allah French-kissing Uncle Sam—which, let me make it very clear, I have not done—than it is to speak honestly about this topic.”
title: Confessions of a Juggler

author: Thomas Lake
summary: The story of H1N1 and one of the lives it claimed.
title: The Golden Boy and the Invisible Army

author: Dominick Dunne
summary: A comprehensive history of the case against the Menendez brothers, built primarily on secret audio recording made by their self-promoting therapist.
title: Nightmare on Elm Drive

author: Christopher Glazek
summary: The abridged history of a Brooklyn culture war.
title: Hasids vs. Hipsters

author: Garry Kasparov
summary: “If genius is hard to define, madness is even more so.” One chess champion’s take on the tortured life of another.
title: The Bobby Fischer Defense

author: Chris Heath
summary: A melancholic Billy Ray Cyrus on the trauma of being the father of a famous 18-year-old girl, his friendship with Kurt Cobain, and his favorite mullet nicknames (Kentucky Waterfall and Missouri Compromise).
title: Mr. Hannah Montana’s Achy Broken Heart

author: Helen Pidd, Martin Chulov
summary: How an Iraqi expat conned the United States, without ever once being interviewed by an American official, into making the case that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. “Believe me, there was no other way to bring about freedom to Iraq.”
title: The Confessions of 'Curveball'

author: Peter Biskind
summary: How the Weinstein Brothers barked their way into an empire and then lost it.
title: The Weinstein Way

author: Steve Kornacki
summary: On 30 years of Long Island politics.
title: The Fall of the Nassau Republican Machine and the Rise of Homeland Security Chair Peter King

author: Sam Kinght
summary: In 2006, seven men stole £53m. Six were caught, but more than half the money remains at large. On modern money laundering best practices.
title: The Search for the Securitas Millions

author: Graeme Wood
summary: The Ugandan rebel Lord’s Resistance Army, drawn mostly from kidnapped children, has proved as elusive as it is barbaric.
title: Joseph Kony's Long Walk To, and From, Hell

author: Cienna Madrid
summary: With Washington State debating a bill that would force Christian pregnancy centers to be more forthright about their anti-abortion agenda, a pair of reporters hear firsthand what the centers are telling young women.
title: Six Pregnancy Tests in One Week

author: Matt Taibbi
summary: “The entire system set up to monitor and regulate Wall Street is fucked up. Just ask the people who tried to do the right thing.”
title: Why Isn't Wall Street in Jail?

author: Chris Smith
summary: SNL in its grim twentieth season through the lens of first (and only) year cast-member Janeane Garofalo.
title: Comedy Isn't Funny

author: Malcolm Gladwell
summary: A grandmother from Chicago, she’s one of those people who knows everybody. And those people who know everybody, the connectors, make the world work. A study of the power of (offline) social networking.
title: Six Degrees of Lois Weisberg

author: George Orwell
summary: An essay on motivation.
title: Why I Write

author: Atul Gawande
summary: How focusing on the neediest patients could radically reduce health care costs.
title: The Hot Spotters

author: Hunter S. Thompson, Ian Johnston
summary: In 1998, a reporter called up Thompson to discuss the Clinton scandal and film adaptations, among other topics. The complete, previously unpublished transcript of their conversation.
title: An Interview with Hunter S. Thompson

author: Hunter S. Thompson
summary: The first piece of gonzo journalism, annotated.
title: Director's Cut: The Kentucky Derby Is Decadent and Depraved

author: Daniel Voll
summary: Omar Mohammed (most certainly not his real name), a former Iraqi cop, is widely believed to be the most skilled and prolific terrorist hunter alive. Recently, he personally killed two of Al-Qaeda’s senior commanders in Iraq. He has already been shot and blown up, and with U.S. forces on their way out, his chances of survival in Baghdad are slim.
title: The Hunter Becomes the Hunted

author: Tina Rosenberg
summary: What Egypt learned from the students who overthrew Milosevic. “The Serbs are not the usual highly paid consultants in suits from wealthy countries; they look more like, well, cocky students. They bring a cowboy swagger. They radiate success. Everyone they teach wants to do what the Serbs did.”
title: Revolution U

author: Evan Ratliff
summary: The search for the genetic distinction that allows certain animals, humans included, to be domesticated.
title: Taming the Wild

author: Gene Weingarten
summary: On writing what you loathe. Leslie McFarlane, ghostwriter of the early Hardy Boys novels, was so ashamed of the work he couldn’t even bring himself to name the books in his diary. “June 9, 1933: Tried to get at the juvenile again today but the ghastly job appalls me.”
title: The Hardy Boys: The Final Chapter...

author: Alexander Star
summary: The oracular works of Philip K. Dick.
title: The God In the Trash

author: Mark Harris
summary: The Top Gun effect; how Hollywood became a factory for sequels, comic book and video game adaptations, and anything else easily marketed to under-25-year-old males.
title: The Day the Movies Died

author: Lisa DePaulo, Kyla Jones
summary: The pecking order of All-Star Weekend sex-with-basketball-player-or-rapper hopefuls.
title: The Days and Nights of an NBA Groupie

author: Andrew Solomon
summary: On Colonel Muammar Qaddafi, “the permanent revolutionary,” and his son Seif.
title: Letter from Libya: Circle of Fire

author: Nat Hentoff
summary: Six months after playing an electric guitar at the Newport Folk Festival, a rambling Dylan holds forth on style, songwriting, and fame. “People have one great blessing—obscurity—and not really too many people are thankful for it.”
title: Playboy Interview: Bob Dylan

author: Larry McMurtry
summary: On photographing the former Norma Jeane Mortenson. ”I think she was the best light comedienne we have in films today, and anyone will tell you that the toughest of acting styles is light comedy.”—Billy Wilder
title: Marilyn

author: Dan Kaufman
summary: A suitcase was smuggled from Spain to Mexico during the Spanish Civil War containing negatives from three photographers would later become legends and all die in war zones. The suitcase disappeared.
title: The Mexican Suitcase

author: Paul Berczeller
summary: In 2001, a young Japanese woman walked into the North Dakota woods and froze to death. Had she come in search of the $1 million dollars buried nearby in the film Fargo?
title: Death in the Snow

author: Caitlin Flanagan
summary: “I had inherited a Rolodex full of useful phone numbers (the College Board, a helpful counselor in the UCLA admissions office), but the number I kept handing out was that of a family therapist.”
title: Confessions of a Prep School College Counselor

author: Steven Hyden
summary: “By the time we got to Woodstock 99 …” In a grim finale, the nineties get their Altamont.
title: Whatever Happened to Alternative Nation? Part 10: 1999

author: Krista Ninivaggi, Nicola Twilley
summary: An interview with Alan Stillman, who in 1965 founded T.G.I. Friday’s, the first singles bar in America.
title: A Cocktail Party In The Street

author: Henry Shukman
summary: Twenty-five years later, inside the Exclusion Zone.
title: Chernobyl, My Primeval, Teeming, Irradiated Eden

author: Ken Silverstein
summary: A profile of Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue, the Malibu-dwelling, “fantastically corrupt” dictator-in-waiting of Equatorial Guinea. Teodorin, as his friends call him, is considered by U.S. intelligence to be “an unstable, reckless idiot.”
title: Teodorin's World

author: Eliza Griswold
summary: One of most popular Libyan figures amongst Western intellectuals and democracy advocates is… Qaddafi’s second son, Saif.
title: The Heir

author: Lisa Belkin
summary: A profile of Heather Armstrong, a mom in Salt Lake City who has more than 1.5 million Twitter followers and a personal blog generating $30,000-$50,000 monthly.
title: Queen of the Mommybloggers

author: David Foster Wallace, Dave Eggers
summary: “The writer/speaker has certain political convictions or affiliations, and proceeds to filter all reality and spin all assertion according to those convictions and loyalties. Everybody’s pissed off and exasperated and impervious to argument from any other side.”
title: David Foster Wallace Interviewed by Dave Eggers

author: L. Jon Wertheim
summary: The bizarre tale–and unlikely turnaround–of an NHL player who tried to have his youth coach murdered.
title: "I'm Glad I Went to Prison"

author: Matt Bai
summary: On the evolution of New Jersey’s governor.
title: How Chris Christie Did His Homework

author: Peter Biskind
summary: Five years ago, Mel Gibson was one of Hollywood’s few genuine family-men and a leading box office attraction; inside his wild descent from star to pariah.
title: The Rude Warrior

author: Julian Dibbell
summary: How virtual worlds like Ultima Online form economies and the sellers who make a living in digital goods.
title: The Unreal Estate Boom

author: Mark McClusky
summary: Tackling the science of cooking, one perfect french fry at a time.
title: Microsoft’s Former CTO Takes On Modernist Cuisine

author: Jason Zengerle
summary: Henry Heimlich saved untold choking victimes when he invented his maneuver in 1974. Since then, he’s searched in vain for another miracle treatment—pushing ethical boundaries along the way. Now at the end of his career, Heimlich has hired an investigator to find an anonymous critic working full-time to destroy his legacy.
title: The Choke Artist

author: James Ellroy
summary: She was last seen leaving a pickup bar, her body was found the next morning in the dirt beside a football field. He was ten. Thirty-six years later, the author investigates his mother’s murder.
title: My Mother's Killer

author: Max Rodenbeck
summary: On the structural underpinnings of the revolts currently shaking the Arab world.
title: 'Volcano of Rage'

author: Rany Jazayerli
summary: Nineteenth century Muslim-Christian hero Abd el-Kader, the “Algerian George Washington.”
title: Abd el-Kader and the Massacre of Damascus.

author: Amy Wallace
summary: The Gabrielle Giffords shooting, from the vantage point of three central figures: Daniel Hernandez helped save the congresswoman’s life; Patricia Maisch stopped the shooter from reloading; Bill Badger tackled him.
title: "I Heard the Shots and Ran Toward the Sound"

author: Molly Lambert
summary: On existing as a girl in the boy’s club that is the world.
title: Can't Be Tamed: A Manifesto

author: Amy Wallace
summary: GQ moved up the release of this Charlie Sheen profile: "The fucking AA shit. The sobriety shit. It was always for other people. I just wanted to get a job back and get enough money to tell everybody to go fuck themselves and then roll like Errol Flynn and Frank Sinatra—the good parts of those guys."
title: Coke, Hookers, Hospital, Repeat

author: Steve Fishman
summary: “One evening, my home phone rang. ‘You have a collect call from Bernard Madoff, an inmate at a federal prison,’ a recording announced. And there he was.”
title: The Madoff Tapes

author: C.J. Chivers
summary: First-person accounts from the 2004 siege of a Russian school in Beslan by Chechen terrorists.
title: The School

author: Andrew Sullivan
summary: A manifesto from one of the first professional bloggers on a new ‘golden age of journalism.’
title: Why I Blog

author: Raymond Chandler
summary: As early as 1948, the Oscars sucked.
title: Oscar Night in Hollywood

author: Alexis Madrigal
summary: How a journalism professor named Dan Sinker became the most entertaining part of the Chicago mayoral race.
title: Revealing the Man Behind @MayorEmanuel

author: David Remnick
summary: On the future of the liberal Israeli newspaper Haartez.
title: The Dissenters

author: Amy Wallace
summary: How the culture of academia helped Amy Bishop, a University of Alabama scientist who murdered colleagues during a faculty meeting, fall apart.
title: What Made This University Scientist Snap?

author: Alex Ross
summary: “I hate classical music: not the thing but the name. It traps a tenaciously living art in a theme park of the past. It cancels out the possibility that music in the spirit of Beethoven could still be created today.”
title: Excerpted from 'Listen to This'

author: Roxane Gay
summary: The Jheri Curl revisited.
title: May Your Hair Mark the Path Behind You

author: Michael Specter
summary: A profile of the (now former) director of the House of Dior, John Galliano.
title: The Fantasist

author: David Wain, Toph Eggers
summary: The comedian and veteran of MTV’s The State on a peculiar brand of stardom. “Often people would be like, I’m such a big fan of your work. I think you’re amazing. I want to have a career like yours. And I’m like, great, can you buy me a slice of pizza?”
title: Interview: David Wain

author: Harold Meyerson
summary: Relative to the total national income, American corporations are making more money than they have since 1947. The connection behind soaring profits and stagnant unemployment.
title: Business Is Booming

author: Alexander Zaitchik
summary: A profile of Alex Jones, who draws a bigger online audience than Glenn Beck and Rush Limbaugh combined.
title: The Most Paranoid Man in America

author: Joe Tone
summary: Kansas City’s most powerful political journalist is a 36-year-old blogger who resides in a porn lair in his mother’s basement, posting rants on local government and bikini shots 24-hours-a-day.
title: Welcome to Tony's Kansas City

author: Ariel Bleicher
summary: The challenges facing the historians of the internet.
title: A Memory of Webs Past

author: Michael Finkel
summary: Daniel Kish is entirely sightless. So how can he ride a bike on busy streets? Go hiking for days alone? By using a technique borrowed from bats.
title: The Blind Man Who Taught Himself to See

author: Michael Joseph Gross
summary: “While its source remains something of a mystery, Stuxnet is the new face of 21st-century warfare: invisible, anonymous, and devastating.”
title: A Declaration of Cyber-War

author: David Corn, Siddhartha Mahanta
summary: What did $3M paid to a US consulting firm get Qaddafi? A glowing profile in The New Republic, written by a Harvard professor, who travelled to Tripoli to interview him. On the consulting company’s dime. Which he failed to disclose.
title: From Libya With Love

author: David Kirkpatrick
summary: A profile of Jack Dorsey, co-founder (and displaced CEO) of Twitter. Dorsey’s latest venture, a mobile credit card system called Square that only officially launched in February 2011, already processes more than a million transactions per day.
title: Twitter Was Act One

author: Gus Garcia-Roberts
summary: The decades-long saga of Miami’s Take Once Cocktail Lounge, where you might get shot, your money will definitely be laundered, and everybody will know your name.
title: Mayhem and Murder Rule at This Little Strip Club

author: Roger Lowenstein
summary: On who will bear the burden of the financial crisis facing cities across America. “Will it be articulated in terms of bond defaults or larger kindergarten classes—or no kindergarten classes at all?”
title: Broke Town, U.S.A.

author: Ian Parker
summary: The definitive story of a ubiquitous software. PowerPoint’s origins, its evolution, and its mind-boggling impact on corporate culture.
title: Absolute PowerPoint

author: Pauline Kael
summary: Hollywood makes bad movies because “rotten pictures make money.”
title: Why Are Movies So Bad? Or, The Numbers

author: Jennifer Egan
summary: After nearly 15 years in a Peruvian prison, an American woman convicted of aiding a Marxist terrorist group finds parole in Lima full of contradictions.
title: The Liberation of Lori Berenson

author: Alex Morris
summary: A crusading minister has built a forested Utopia for the itinerant and destitute. But is a social experiment what they’re looking for, or just a place to live?
title: A Homeless City in the Woods

author: Charlie LeDuff
summary: A series of first-person essays on a reporter’s relationship with his city. Excerpted from the upcoming Detroit: An American Autopsy.
title: My Detroit Story

author: Chris Anderson
summary: The article that spawned a school of thought; an elegy for the age of the megahit and a primer for the niche-based future.
title: The Long Tail

author: Carl Swanson
summary: On Trey Parker, Matt Stone, and their new Broadway musical about Mormons, which “may just be their highest artistic achievement yet.”
title: Latter-Day Saints

author: Tess Lynch
summary: Thoughts on the current era of online anonymity.
title: Who You Are and Who You Say You Are

author: Robert Draper
summary: Stuck between the Taliban and the U.S. Military, Afghanistan’s farmers risk their lives both when they grow, and when they refuse to grow, fields of poppies.
title: Opium Wars

author: Emily Badger
summary: Passengers get a free ride. Drivers get a passport to the HOV lane. Nobody pays, nobody talks. On “slugging,” the DIY commuter system in D.C. that’s being used by 10,000 people a day and taking thousands of cars off the road.
title: Slugging—The People's Transit

author: Jonathan Garrett
summary: An oral history of the Strokes.
title: This Is It: Ten Years of the Strokes

author: Tom Cheshire
summary: Inside the most ubiquitous distraction of its era.
title: How Rovio made Angry Birds a Winner

author: Eric Puchner
summary: Memories of the author’s teenage years, when his father pulled up stakes on a comfortable life in Baltimore to reinvent himself as the head of a S&L bank in Los Angeles.
title: Schemes of My Father

author: Benjamin J. Dueholm
summary: How Dan Savage became America’s leading ethicist.
title: Rules of Misbehavior

author: John Conroy
summary: A veteran reporter investigates his own beating.
title: A Mugging on Lake Street

author: Evan Wright
summary: Published across three consecutive issues and later adapted into the book (and mini-series) Generation Kill, the story of bullets, bombs and a Marine platoon at war in Iraq.Previously: Evan Wright on the Longform Podcast.
title: The Killer Elite

author: James Fallows
summary: Is it time to end the mourning period for old media?
title: Learning to Love the (Shallow, Divisive, Unreliable) New Media

author: Wade Roush
summary: The next frontier of search is… everything. Voice recognition, image recognition, and why Google’s data set is one of the most valuable scientific tools of our age.
title: Inside Google’s Age of Augmented Humanity (Pt. 1-3)

author: Chris Rock, Scott Raab
summary: "Howard Stern's a bad motherfucker, man..if I had to be on six hours a day, it would be just as nasty and foul and not sophisticated. The fact that you're going to see me do an hour every four years? Reduce Howard Stern to an hour every four years, you'd have the most brilliant comedian who ever lived. It's not even close."
title: Interview: Chris Rock

author: Samantha Shapiro
summary: Inside the world of 10-and-under competitive cheerleading.
title: They Grow Up So Fast

author: S.L. Price
summary: A profile of the highest paid coach in college basketball. A pioneer of one-and-done recruiting, Calipari is also the only coach in NCAA history to have two runs to the Final Four removed from the record books for rules violations.
title: Too Slick, Too Loud, Too Successful: Why John Calipari Can't Catch a Break

author: Michael Sokolove
summary: On Baylor’s freshman basketball star Perry Jones and how the new era of one-season careers has changed the landscape of college basketball.
title: Dunk and Done

author: Denise Grollmus
summary: One part rapist, one part con-man; the story of the seemingly unconvictable Hy Doan.
title: Sex Thief

author: Robert S. Boynton
summary: The perilous routes through which information—video footage, secret documents, radio broadcasts—flow in and out of North Korea through its porous borders with China.
title: North Korea’s Digital Underground

author: Vanessa Grigoriadis
summary: “If 4chan sounds trivial, that’s because it is. The site certainly doesn’t make much money…In fact, you could say that 4chan has cornered the market on the trivial on the Internet, which is no small feat (the trivial usually spreads by accident on the Web, according to no logic).”
title: 4Chan's Chaos Theory

author: Lisa Katayama
summary: Inside the thriving subculture of Japanese men who eschew sex and romance with real live people in favor of real relationships with 2-D characters printed on body pillows.
title: Love in 2-D

author: Mac McClelland
summary: A first-person account of the author’s time spent volunteering with a group of Burmese activists in Thailand, who turn out to be not Korean but in fact Karen, members of Burma’s persecuted ethnic minority. In the course of her time there, they show her videos of their risky forays across the border, and she shows them MySpace.
title: For Us Surrender Is Out of the Question

author: Maciej Ceglowski
summary: A technical, thrilling account of how Pinboard, a tiny bookmarking service, dealt with the fire hose of new users after news leaked that Yahoo would discontinue Pinboard’s massive rival, Delicious.
title: Anatomy of a Crushing

author: Hilton Als
summary: On the life and career of Richard Pryor, as he neared the end of both.
title: A Pryor Love

author: Jason Fried
summary: An entrepreneurial primer from the founder of 37Signals. “So here’s a great way to practice making money: Buy and sell the same thing over and over on Craigslist or eBay. Seriously.”
title: How to Get Good at Making Money

author: Pamela Colloff
summary: Why did a small-town girl have her family brutally murdered?
title: Flesh and Blood

author: A. A. Gill
summary: The surreal afterlife of the once-ascendant Dubai, where “the legacy of oil has made everything worthless.”
title: Dubai on Empty

author: Mark Singer
summary: A profile of the filmmaker Errol Morris as he prepared to release The Thin Blue Line after a decade of limited distribution, semi-poverty, and a side career as a private detective.
title: Predilections

author: Jay Dixit
summary: On being the lone male student at a women’s college.
title: The Highly-Charged Erotic Life of the Wellesley Girl

author: Chris Norris
summary: Is Dr. Drew’s “Celebrity Rehab” therapy or tabloid voyeurism?
title: Hitting Bottom

author: Michael Paterniti
summary: Depending on who you ask, Mohammed Jawad was either 12 or 17 when he was detained. Nobody disputes that he spent seven years at Guantánamo before he was exonerated. The story of a boy who grew up as a detainee.
title: The Boy from Gitmo

author: Helen Pearson
summary: A group of scientists started tracking thousands of British children born during one cold March week in 1946. Those children are now 65 and the data generated through careful tracking of their life history has become extremely valuable.
title: Epidemiology: Study of a Lifetime

author: Kliph Nesteroff
summary: “Every Sunday at my house … we watched The Ed Sullivan Show…. Whether we enjoyed it or not. That was my first lesson in show business. I don’t think anybody in the house particularly enjoyed it. We just watched it. Maybe that’s the purpose of television. You just turn it on and watch it whether you want to or not.”
title: The Early David Letterman 1967-1980

author: Seth Mnookin
summary: A Red Sox fan profiles the Yankee captain.
title: Derek Jeter's Swinging Years

author: Caren Zucker, John Donvan
summary: The long, happy, surprising life of 77-year old Donald Gary Triplett, the first person ever diagnosed with autism.
title: Autism's First Child

author: Michael Kimmelman
summary: Peter Zumthor, who recently won the Pritzker Prize after a career of few buildings and mostly modest-in-size projects, on the “architecture of actually making things”
title: The Ascension of Peter Zumthor

author: Dana Goodyear
summary: Barry Michels is Hollywood’s most successful therapist cum motivation coach with an approach that combines Jungian psychology, encouraging patients to embrace their dark side, and “three-by-five index cards inscribed with Delphic pronouncements like THE HIERARCHY WILL NEVER BE CLEAR.”
title: Hollywood Shadows: A Cure for Blocked Screenwriters

author: Julie Kavanagh
summary: A profile of Grace Coddington, creative director of Vogue and break-out star of The September Issue.
title: Creative Indeed

author: J.M. Ledgard
summary: How smartphones are changing a continent.
title: Digital Africa

author: James Verini
summary: An artifact from the era when MySpace was king.
title: Will Success Spoil MySpace?

author: Matthieu Aikins
summary: An undercover report on Afghanistan’s drug-smuggling border police that is now heavily used for intelligence training.
title: The Master of Spin Boldak

author: Scott Horton
summary: On January 27th in Lahore, an American named Raymond A. Davis stopped his Honda Civic and shot two Pakistani men, then made a failed attempt to flee. Beyond those basic facts, little is agreed upon, and the murders have ignited a diplomatic crisis, which only intensified with the revelation that Davis was a CIA subcontractor.
title: Spy Games

author: Tim Layden
summary: The story of the 2010 NCAA championship game between Duke and Butler, and what would have been greatest shot in college basketball history.
title: A Fling and a Prayer

author: Kenneth Tynan
summary: On Johnny Carson, a cold man in a hot seat.
title: Fifteen Years of the Salto Mortale

author: Shani O. Hilton
summary: A young black gentrifier gets lumped in with both groups, often depending on what she’s wearing and where she’s drinking. She is always aware of that fact.
title: Confessions of a Black Gentrifier in D.C.

author: Mac McClelland
summary: On reservations, where policing hardly exists, bruiser-for-hire vigilantes are often the first choice for justice.
title: A Fistful of Dollars

author: Alex Pappademas
summary: A profile of Zack Snyder, director of Watchmen, Dawn of the Dead, and the upcoming Superman series.
title: Hollywood's Leading Geek

author: Michael E. Miller
summary: If you hit a bar or restaurant in South Miami, there’s a good chance Eddie Santana has waited tables there. And then sued. Sometimes after only a single day on the job.
title: Restaurant Rebel

author: Randall Sullivan
summary: One of the most valuable cars in the world crashes going 200 mph on the Pacific Coast Highway. Its owner claims to be an anti-terrorism officer. In fact, he’s a former executive at a failed software company—and a career criminal. The unraveling of an epic con.
title: Gizmondo's Spectacular Crack-Up

author: Dan P. Lee
summary: Intended for cremation, 244 bodies are instead harvested for organs and tissue. The story of the families of the dead, the men who profited off the scheme, and the unwitting recipients of black market body parts.
title: Body Snatchers

author: Robert Greenfield
summary: On the many lives and careers of Owsley Stanley (1935-2011), chemist, sound design innovator, and outback jeweler, whose name appears in the OED as a synonym for “a particularly pure form of LSD.”
title: The King of LSD

author: Evan Osnos
summary: On the ground in post-disaster Japan.
title: Aftershocks

author: Kliph Nesteroff
summary: The swinging life and boozy death of the original ladies man, and the story of “the coroner that tampered with his cold, lifeless venereal warts.”
title: The Voyeuristic Adventures of Errol Flynn

author: Ashley Parker, Alison Leigh Cowan, Michael Barbaro
summary: On the mysterious relationship between a major New York State power broker and a Brooklyn family. “The Turanos are variously described by friends, neighbors and colleagues as the senator’s social acquaintances, lovers or surrogate relatives.”
title: A Senator’s Shadow Family

author: Douglas Goetsch
summary: After the 1919 Black Sox scandal, Ring Lardner, America’s first great sportswriter, walked away from the game.
title: Baseball’s Loss of Innocence

author: Luc Sante
summary: On Don DeLillo’s Underworld.
title: Between Hell and History

author: Luc Sante, Geoffrey O'Brien
summary: A conversation on the Times Square of the ’50s and ’60s.
title: Interview: Geoffrey O'Brien

author: Michael Lewis
summary: In the late ’80s, Lewis went to Japan to research a hypothetical: what would the economic fallout be if a major quake hit?
title: How a Tokyo Earthquake Could Devastate Wall Street and the World Economy

author: Susan Orlean
summary: A profile of a 25-year-old Spanish sensation.
title: La Matadora Revisa Su Maquillaje (The Bullfighter Checks Her Makeup)

author: Susan Orlean
summary: On surfer girls in Maui; the story that led to the film Blue Crush.
title: Life's Swell

author: Daphne Merkin
summary: The life that he has created almost from scratch over the last two years has been defined at least as much by what Tyson wants to avoid — old haunts, old habits, old temptations and old hangers-on — as by what he wants to embrace.
title: The Suburbanization of Mike Tyson

author: Drake Bennett
summary: Sasha Shulgin, a former DOW chemist who now lives a quiet life as a pensioner outside the Bay Area, is responsible for the discovery of the majority of psychedelic compounds currently known.
title: Dr. Ecstasy

author: Daniel Zwerdling, T. Christian Miller
summary: In January 2009, a U.S. platoon came under rocket attack in Iraq. Two years later, how the event changed the soldiers’ lives.
title: Aftershock: The Blast That Shook Psycho Platoon

author: Errol Morris, Philip Gourevitch
summary: A profile of Sabrina Harman, the soldier who took many of the notorious Abu Ghraib photographs.
title: Exposure

author: Monica Potts
summary: Immigrant farmers are flocking to the poultry industry -- only to become 21st-century sharecroppers for companies like Tyson.
title: The Serfs of Arkansas

summary: In the 1880’s, a shabbily dressed man popped up in numerous America cities, calling upon local scientists, showing letters of introduction claiming he was a noted geologist or paleontologist, discussing both fields at a staggeringly accomplished level, and then making off with valuable books or cash loans.
title: The Saga of the Scientific Swindler!

author: Dominick Dunne
summary: On Elizabeth Taylor at the height of her fame.
title: The Queen and I

author: Perry Anderson
summary: A 12,000-word profile of recently departed Brazilian President Luiz Inácio da Silva, the “most successful politician of his time.”
title: Lula's Brazil

author: Tom Junod
summary: A profile of computational biologist Eric Schadt, the guy who’s figuring out what comes next after the Human Genome Project.
title: Adventures in Extreme Science

author: Max Chafkin
summary: A story written about Twitter and one its founders, Evan Williams, when the company’s chief source of revenue was subletting desks in their partially filled office.
title: Anything Could Happen

author: Tim Rogers
summary: The closest thing that the international network of hackers Anonymous has to an organizer lives in a 378 sq. ft apartment in Dallas and, at the time of this interview, was on his fourth day of opiate withdrawal.
title: How Barrett Brown Helped Overthrow Tunisia's Government

author: Nick Pinto
summary: The underage prostitution study that was cited extensively in the congressional hearings that resulted in the removal of Craigslist’s Erotic Services turns out to be the work of a for-hire business consulting firm and, scientifically, completely bogus.
title: Women's Funding Network Sex Trafficking Study Is Junk Science

author: Skip Hollandsworth
summary: The story of Dean Corll and his accomplices, who killed over 20 teenage boys in the Heights neighborhood of Houston in the early 1970s, and the families searching for their missing sons.
title: The Lost Boys

author: Anthony Shadid, Lynsey Addario, Stephen Farrell, Tyler Hicks
summary: No one really knows the script for days like these, and neither did we.
title: 4 Times Journalists Held in Libya Faced Brutality

author: Noah Shachtman
summary: Investigating the investigation of the 2001 anthrax attacks.
title: Anthrax Redux: Did the Feds Nab the Wrong Guy?

author: Paul LaFarge
summary: Why utopias are best understood as fiction games, and how they quickly become dystopias when realized.
title: Utopia & Dystopia

author: Jack Olsen, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar
summary: “My name is Ferdinand Lewis Alcindor Jr., and my name is also Abdul Kareem, but I’ll explain about that much later.” A three-part personal essay on basketball, family, race and religion.
title: My Story

author: Jay Caspian Kang
summary: A profile of 21-year-old Dan Cates, who made $5.5 million playing 145,215 hands in 2010.
title: Online Poker's Big Winner

author: William Langewiesche
summary: The unlikely ascent of A.Q. Khan, the scientist who gave Pakistan the Bomb, and his suspicious fall from grace.
title: The Wrath of Khan (Part 1)

author: William Langewiesche
summary: Did A.Q. Khan sell nuclear secrets on the black market? The fame had unbalanced him. He was subjected to a degree of public acclaim rarely seen in the West—an extreme close to idol worship, which made him hungry for more. Money seems never to have been his obsession, but it did play a role.
title: The Point of No Return (Part 2)

author: David Holthouse
summary: Schaeffer Cox, who is accused of plotting to kill State Troopers and a federal judge, shifted rapidly from a Ron Paul campaign worker and Tea Party activist to a hardcore militia leader. His conspiracy revealed, mainstream Alaskan politicians are scrambling to distance themselves from their ties to Cox.
title: Palling Around with Terrorists

author: David Grann
summary: Rodrigo Rosenberg, a highly respected corporate attorney in Guatemala, began, in the spring of 2009, to prophesy his own murder. The unraveling of a political conspiracy.
title: A Murder Foretold

author: Brian Boucher
summary: A New Yorker finds an unlikely house guest on Craigslist.
title: My Roommate, The Diamond Thief

author: Mark Boal
summary: How U.S. soldiers in Afghanistan murdered innocent civilians and mutilated their corpses – and how their officers failed to stop them.
title: The Kill Team

author: Virginia Heffernan
summary: A profile of a pre-30 Rock Tina Fey.
title: Anchor Woman

author: M.J. Hyland
summary: Last summer, when she thought nobody was looking, Mary Bale put a cat in the trash. The act was caught on video, and Bale was quickly tried and convicted online. The aftermath of a viral crime.
title: The Trial of Mary Bale

author: Pablo S. Torre
summary: Five years after they leave the league, 60 percent of NBA players have nothing left. In the NFL, it’s closer to 80 percent after just two years. On the economics of professional sports.
title: How and (Why) Athletes Go Broke

author: Jonathan Dee
summary: How Dennis from Head of the Class grew up to be the Aaron Sorkin of tween television.
title: Tween on the Screen

author: Alice Gregory
summary: "I have the sensation, as do my friends, that to function as a proficient human, you must both 'keep up' with the internet and pursue more serious, analog interests."An essay on technology’s reach into daily life.

title: How Slavery Really Ended in America

author: Arthur Allen
summary: Energy problems are long problems that often receive short solutions. In 2000, when Mother Jones ran this history about what happened to the energy research boom of the late 70s and early 80s, I was buying $0.99 a gallon gas for my Escort. I chose this story because I think longform journalism can keep people interested in these issues that require decadal attention but are subject to year-to-year fluctuations in public interest. And it’s a great story.  -A. Madrigal
title: Prodigal Sun

author: Steven Levy
summary: Steven Levy’s piece on cypherpunks and Internet libertarians could not feel more relevant in the wake of WikiLeaks’ rise and the heavily scrutinized role of online organizing in recent revolutions. During Wired’s first year, I’d just gotten an Internet account and had somehow stumbled on the magazine. It became my guide to this hybrid life that we all live now, half-online, half-offline.-A. Madrigal
title: Crypto Rebels

author: Susannah Breslin
summary: Breslin’s unflinching and devastating investigation of the porn industry in Los Angeles would be at home in many an excellent magazine. But Breslin didn’t go that route. Instead, she built a custom site that presents the story with her photographs and design.-A. Madrigal
title: They Shoot Porn Stars, Don't They?

author: Fred Hapgood
summary: I love combing through The Atlantic’s archives. There’s almost no better way of grasping the strangeness of the past than to flip through a general interest magazine from 1960. Here, we find Fred Hapgood grappling with what human intelligence meant in the light of new machines that could do something like thinking.Intelligence was being explored in a new way: by finding out what was duplicable about how our minds work. Hapgood's conclusion was that if you could automate a task, it would lose value to humans. What tremendous luck! Humans value that which only humans can do, he argued, regardless of the difficulty of the task. And that because computers were so good at sequential logic problems, we'd eventually end up only respecting emotional understanding, which remained (and remains) beyond the reach of AI.-A. Madrigal
title: Computers Aren’t So Smart, After All

author: David Graeber
summary: This is the piece of writing that inspired me to make the turn from fiction and corporate research into journalism. It’s the best reframing of American society that I’ve ever read. And kudos to Harper’s for running it. It’s not often you see anarchist anthropologists making highly visible contributions to public discourse.-A. Madrigal
title: Army of Altruists

summary: Bernard Peters and his son, Scott, robbed and shot a Salvation Army worker in 1996. Since then, they’ve been sharing a cell at Elmira Correctional Facility.
title: Father and Son, Bunking in G Block

author: Ross Perlin
summary: On internships at Disney World, where “labor is meant to have an almost invisible quality.”
title: Down and Out in the Magic Kingdom

author: Katie Baker
summary: On recommitting to the Knicks after “a decade of dysfunction and delusion.”
title: The Garden of Good and Evil

author: Steve Oney
summary: The story of the 1969 murder spree by Charles Manson and “Family” as told by those close to the case.
title: Manson: An Oral History

author: Alex Morris
summary: The social rituals of the pansexual, bi-queer, metroflexible New York teen.
title: The Cuddle Puddle of Stuyvesant High School

author: Richard Cahan
summary: In June, 1942, a German submarine dropped four young Nazi agents off on a Florida beach. Their mission was to blow up bridges, factories, and Jewish-owned department stores. Among them was Herbert Haupt, the 22-year-old son of a German-American family in Chicago.
title: A Terrorist's Tale

author: Rick Reilly
summary: On the talent, ego, and late father of Bryant Gumbel.
title: The Mourning Anchor

author: Dane Batty
summary: A bank robber tells the story of a successful heist.
title: The Double

author: Evan Fleischer
summary: Nearly 10,000,000 men were killed in the conflict, 65 million participated, and now we are left with two.
title: The Last Two Veterans Of WWI

author: Silas Bent
summary: Confessions of a yellow journalist: Let me say that I did very little faking, although there was no special prejudice against it, so long as the fake wasn't libelous.
title: Journalism and Morality

author: Gus Garcia-Roberts
summary: The demise of an NFL player.
title: Dave Duerson's Secret Life and Tragic End

author: Daniel Mendelsohn
summary: On tragedy, mythology, and the spectacular crash of the Spider-Man musical and its creator, Julie Taymor.
title: Why She Fell

author: Wil S. Hylton
summary: What happened to Air France Flight 447?
title: The Deepest End

author: Junot Díaz
summary: On Haiti and why apocalypse, by definition, must include revelation.
title: Apocalypse

author: Brendan Kiley
summary: The anatomy of a bungled, massively expensive undercover sting conducted by the Seattle Police Department.
title: The Long Con

author: Michael Specter
summary: Inside a chess master’s fiefdom.
title: Planet Kirsan

author: Pamela Colloff
summary: Odessa High School students know her as “Betty,” a ghost that haunts the auditorium at night.  But few know much about the real Betty, whose 1961 murder was “the most sensational crime in West Texas in its day.”
title: A Kiss Before Dying

author: Andrew Marshall
summary: Manny Pacquiao, possibly the greatest boxer of his era and still in his fighting prime, on the campaign trail for a congressional seat in the remote, untamed Southern province of the Phillipines that spawned him.
title: Atomic: How Manny Pacquiao Got To Congress

author: Jonathan Alter
summary: On Hillary Clinton’s Arab Spring.
title: Woman of the World

author: Steve Bogira
summary: When he was 16, Mark Clements talked his way into four life sentences. Twenty-eight years later, he talked his way out.
title: A Convict's Odyssey

author: Fredric Dannen
summary: The questionable close relationship between a mobster/informant and an F.B.I. agent during a bloody Colombo crime family battle.
title: The G-Man and the Hit Man

author: Steve Silberman
summary: The placebo response doesn't care if the catalyst for healing is a triumph of pharmacology, a compassionate therapists, or a syringe of salt water. All it requires is a reasonable expectation of getting better.
title: Placebos Are Getting More Effective. Drugmakers Are Desperate to Know Why.

author: Martha Sherrill
summary: A profile of Maine’s two U.S. senators, Olympia Snowe and Susan Collins.
title: Maine senators may not like each other much, but they share love of state, job

author: Peter Pomerantsev
summary: The investigation of 20-year-old Russian model’s fall from a Manhattan rooftop uncovers a string of mysteries and clues embedded within the insular world of international models and those who scout them.
title: Disconcerting New Answers In Models Suicide

author: Donald MacKenzie
summary: How automated ‘execution algorithms’ are taking the world’s markets on a wild ride that few economists can even understand, much less control.
title: How to Make Money in Microseconds

author: Lawrence Wright
summary: The unintended consequences of American funding in Pakistan.
title: The Double Game

author: John McPhee
summary: A study of the Mississippi River, its history, and efforts by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to hold it in place.
title: The Control of Nature: Atchafalaya

author: Michael Finkel
summary: Three teenage boys decide to set sail after a night of drinking.  They go missing for 51 days.
title: Here Be Monsters

author: Javier Marias, Sarah Fay
summary: In the past the only people who wrote autobiographies or memoirs were very important, those who had a crucial role in the history of their own country—Napoleon, Goethe—or were witness to major events or people who had singular, adventurous lives. Otherwise, it is ridiculous to write your autobiography.
title: Javier Marias: The Art of Fiction No. 190

author: Carl Swanson
summary: Justin Vivian Bond found downtown fame as Kiki DuRane, decrepit drag chanteuse and comedic prophet of gay rage born out of the AIDS era. Then he killed Kiki to try to become the woman (and man) he always wanted to be.
title: The Story of V

author: Wesley Yang
summary: What becomes of Asian-American overachievers after the test-taking ends?
title: Paper Tigers

author: Matthew McGough
summary: A murder case in Los Angeles, cold since the late ’80s, heats up thanks to breakthroughs in forensic science and leads detectives to “one of the unlikeliest murder suspects in the city’s history.”
title: The Lazarus File

author: Judith Thurman
summary: The discovery of 30,000-year old, perfectly preserved cave paintings in southern France offer a glimpse into a world that 21st-century humans can never hope to understand. The article that inspired Werner Herzog’s “Cave of Forgotten Dreams.”
title: First Impressions

author: Tom Junod
summary: Doc moves quickly. He takes off his windbreaker, tosses his leather bag on the counter and unzips it. He pulls out a slate-blue polyester vest, V-necked, with six buttons. He raises his arms and jumps into it and then says, with an air of deep satisfaction, "Aah." Doc is proud of his bulletproof vest.
title: The Abortionist

author: Jose Manuel Prieto
summary: On the ground to witness Cuba’s last days: “Either we rectify our course or the time for teetering along on the brink runs out and we go down. And we will go down…[with] the effort of entire generations.”—Raul Castro
title: Havana: The State Retreats

author: Joshua Green
summary: During her brief tenure as governor of Alaska, Sarah Palin was a genuinely effective, bipartisan legislator. What went wrong?
title: The Tragedy of Sarah Palin

author: Elizabeth Dwoskin
summary: The story of a high school quarterback’s descent into madness, and its tragic end.
title: Killing Mom and Dad on Staten Island

author: Gary Wolf
summary: On 21st-century prospectors: Shawn Ryan is the king of a new Yukon gold rush, the biggest since the legendary Klondike stampede a century ago. Behind this stampede is the rising price of gold, and behind this price is fear.
title: Gold Mania in the Yukon

author: Joshua Yaffa
summary: On Edward Tufte, the  great data visualization (read: charts and graphs) theorist and author of 1983’s The Visual Display of Quantitative Information, one of the most successful self-published books ever produced.
title: The Information Sage

author: Matt Taibbi
summary: While much of the Levin report describes past history, the Goldman section describes an ongoing? crime — a powerful, well-connected firm, with the ear of the president and the Treasury, that appears to have conquered the entire regulatory structure and stands now on the precipice of officially getting away with one of the biggest financial crimes in history.
title: The People vs. Goldman Sachs

author: Lynn Hirschberg
summary: A profile of Hole lead singer Courtney Love.
title: Strange Love

author: Leslie Jamison
summary: The story of the 100 mile Barkley Marathons. What makes it so bad? No trail, for one. A cumulative elevation gain that’s nearly twice the height of Everest.
title: The Immortal Horizon

author: Scott Raab
summary: John Demjanjuk has had a huge year. Twenty years after being sentenced to die, he finally climbed to the pinnacle of the Wiesenthal Center's list of Nazi war criminals this April, shortly after the Germans filed the arrest warrant that allowed the OSI to put him on the jet to Munich.
title: John Demjanjuk: The Last Nazi

author: Christopher Bollen, Michael Stipe
summary: When I hear music as a fan, I see fields. I see landscapes. I close my eyes and see an entire universe that that music and the voice, or the narrative, create. A music video-and any other kind of visual reference-is created by someone else. For me, as a music fan, visuals kind of steal away the purity of the song.
title: Interview: Michael Stipe

author: Robert Young Pelton
summary: On the economics of the booming Somali pirate business, which is up 177 percent over last year.
title: Somali Pirates' Rich Returns

author: Barry Bearak
summary: In his first Major League at bat, Adam Greenberg was hit in the head with a fastball. He never made it back.
title: Head Trip

author: David Kushner
summary: Inside Gibsonton, Florida, the carny capital of the nation.
title: I Was a Teenage Freak

author: Bruce LaBruce, Karl Lagerfeld
summary: There’s a price you have to pay for fame, and people who don’t want to pay that price can get in trouble. I accepted the idea of celebrity because of a French expression: “You cannot have the butter and the money for the butter.”
title: Interview: Karl Lagerfeld

author: Emily B. Hager, Mark Mazzetti
summary: Since being revealed as a CIA operative and selling Blackwater, Erik Prince has set to work building U.A.E. a mercenary army, made up heavily of Colombian and South African troops, to be used “if the Emirates faced unrest or were challenged by pro-democracy demonstrations in its crowded labor camps or democracy protests like those sweeping the Arab world this year.”
title: Blackwater Founder Forms Secret Army for Arab State

author: Lester Bangs
summary: Ah yes, you should also know that most of your colleagues are some of the biggest neurotics in the country, so you might as well get used right now to the way they're gonna be writing you five and ten page single spaced inflammatory letters reviling you for knocking some group that they have proved is the next Stones.
title: How to be a Rock Critic & Here's How

author: Emily Nussbaum
summary: Louis C.K. has a deal unlike anyone else’s on TV: his network, FX, has no approval rights and offers no notes. He is also the show’s lone writer, editor, director, and star. A profile.
title: One-Man Show

author: Jane Mayer
summary: How Thomas Drake, senior executive at the NSA, came to face some of the gravest charges that can be brought against an American citizen.
title: The Secret Sharer

author: Eleanor Stanford
summary: A young mother transplants her family to Bahia.
title: Brazil in Three Fruits

author: Vanessa Grigoriadis
summary: A profile Mark Pincus, the founder and C.E.O. of Zynga—the company that created FarmVille, CityVille, and Zynga Poker, the most popular online poker game in the world.
title: Ol’ Mark Pincus Had a Farm…

author: Roseanne Barr
summary: “Winning” in Hollywood means not just power, money, and complimentary smoked-salmon pizza, but also that everyone around you fails just as you are peaking.
title: And I Should Know

author: Sarah Lacy
summary: On the ground in Nigeria with the nation’s notorious scam artists, who share a remarkable number of qualities with America’s top entrepreneurs.
title: The Chilling Story of Genius in a Land of Chronic Unemployment

author: Lars Anderson
summary: The story of a college town and the most devastating tornado in Alabama history.
title: Terror, Tragedy and Hope in Tuscaloosa

author: Marshall McLuhan
summary: Today, in the electronic age of instantaneous communication, I believe that our survival, and at the very least our comfort and happiness, is predicated on understanding the nature of our new environment, because unlike previous environmental changes, the electric media constitute a total and near-instantaneous transformation of culture, values and attitudes.
title: Playboy Interview: Marshall McLuhan

author: Maria Bustillos
summary: On why we need to stop questioning Wikipedia and start thinking about what comes next.
title: Wikipedia And The Death Of The Expert

author: Steven Lee Myers
summary: On the investors betting big on the Iraqi economy, which they believe has nowhere to go but up.
title: The Hot-Money Cowboys of Baghdad

author: Judy Dutton
summary: On the “booming market” for human breast milk.
title: Liquid Gold

author: James Ridgeway, Jean Casella
